citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There was a white adult female goat named “Kenna” visibly limping. Upon closer inspection, she had a small moist lesion
between her left rear hooves. She also had a approximately quarter-sized scabbed over lesion on the mid outer left thigh,
that when squeezed, expressed a small amount of a creamy yellow substance. The goat had not been seen or evaluated
by a veterinarian at the time of the inspection and the representative stated that he hadn't noticed the issue.
Daily observation of all animals in order to assess their health and well-being is an essential element of adequate care,
and any issues related to health and well-being must be promptly communicated to the veterinarian, who can then make a
determination as to whether any additional assessment / intervention / treatment may be needed. Prompt identification of
health problems and the provision of timely, adequate veterinary care is important to ensure animal health and alleviate
suffering and discomfort.
Corrected at time of inspection on Oct 10, 2024.

Two enclosures housing 4 weaned kittens were only 22" tall and lacked elevated resting surfaces. Without sufficient
vertical space to stretch, jump, and rest, cats cannot express species specific behaviors necessary for their welfare. Every
primary enclosure housing cats must be at least 24" tall and contain a resting surface(s) large enough to hold all
occupants of the enclosure at the same time. The surfaces must be elevated high enough that the space under them can
still be comfortably occupied by the animal if desired. Correct by providing adequate vertical space and elevated resting
platforms by Oct 24, 2024.

There was no current written program of veterinary care for review at the time of inspection. Without an established and
written program of veterinary care, USDA cannot assess the level of veterinary care, prevention, and treatment plans of
the two puppies in the kennel. Each licensee must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is
developed, documented in writing, signed by the attending veterinarian. Licensees must maintain the written program and
make it available for APHIS inspection.
Correct by Oct 17, 2024

The perimeter fence at the front of the property measures only 67” in height. All outdoor housing facilities must be
enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height (minimum of 6ft), to keep animals and unauthorized persons out.
The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized
persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a
secondary containment system for the animals in the facility.
Correct by constructing a perimeter fence that is at least 72” surrounding all areas of the facility where regulated species
are housed outdoors by Dec 15, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There was a white adult female goat named “Kenna” visibly limping. Upon closer inspection, she had a small moist lesion 
between her left rear hooves. She also had a approximately quarter-sized scabbed over lesion on the mid outer left thigh, 
that when squeezed, expressed a small amount of a creamy yellow substance. The goat had not been seen or evaluated 
by a veterinarian at the time of the inspection and the representative stated that he hadn't noticed the issue. 
 
Daily observation of all animals in order to assess their health and well-being is an essential element of adequate care, 
and any issues related to health and well-being must be promptly communicated to the veterinarian, who can then make a 
determination as to whether any additional assessment / intervention / treatment may be needed. Prompt identification of 
health problems and the provision of timely, adequate veterinary care is important to ensure animal health and alleviate 
suffering and discomfort.  
 
Corrected at time of inspection on Oct 10, 2024. 
3.6(b)(4) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two enclosures housing 4 weaned kittens were only 22" tall and lacked elevated resting surfaces. Without sufficient 
vertical space to stretch, jump, and rest, cats cannot express species specific behaviors necessary for their welfare. Every 
primary enclosure housing cats must be at least 24" tall and contain a resting surface(s) large enough to hold all 
occupants of the enclosure at the same time. The surfaces must be elevated high enough that the space under them can 
still be comfortably occupied by the animal if desired. Correct by providing adequate vertical space and elevated resting 
platforms by Oct 24, 2024. 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There was no current written program of veterinary care for review at the time of inspection. Without an established and 
written program of veterinary care, USDA cannot assess the level of veterinary care, prevention, and treatment plans of 
the two puppies in the kennel. Each licensee must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is

developed, documented in writing, signed by the attending veterinarian. Licensees must maintain the written program and 
make it available for APHIS inspection. 
Correct by Oct 17, 2024 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The perimeter fence at the front of the property measures only 67” in height. All outdoor housing facilities must be 
enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height (minimum of 6ft), to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. 
The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized 
persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a 
secondary containment system for the animals in the facility.  
Correct by constructing a perimeter fence that is at least 72” surrounding all areas of the facility where regulated species 
are housed outdoors by Dec 15, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
